0.name: Aloe Vera
uses: Soothes burns, sunburns, minor wounds, insect bites
May aid digestion, ulcer healing, and inflammatory bowel conditions
Supports glycemic control and weight management by reducing fat accumulation
howToUse: Apply fresh inner gel directly to burns or wounds several times daily; leave exposed to air
Use aloe gel moisturizer for acne-prone or sensitive skin, 2â€“3 times per day
Drink aloe juice (1 cup liquid + 2 tbsp gel) in smoothies or diluted water for digestion
Consider glass of aloe gel 1â€“2x daily to help lower blood sugar; consult physician for dosage
caution: Allergic reactions (itching, rash) may occurâ€”patch-test before use
Aloe latex is a stimulant laxativeâ€”can cause cramps, diarrhea; unsafe in high doses or long term
Latex may interact with digoxin, diuretics, anticoagulantsâ€”avoid during surgery or if on medication
Oral aloe may be unsafe for pregnant/breastfeeding women and children under 12
Nonâ€‘decolorized whole leaf extract is a possible carcinogen (IARC group 2B)
0.foundIn: Originally from North Africa; now grown worldwide in dry subtropical regions

1.name: Rasna
uses: Reduces inflammation and pain (arthritis, rheumatism, headaches)
Treats coughs, sore throat, respiratory congestion
Improves digestion, relieves gas, stimulates appetite
Fights bacterial infections, may enhance male sexual health
Used to treat fever, menstrual cramps, skin inflammation
howToUse: Boil 2â€“3 slices of fresh rhizome in water to make tea; drink up to twice daily
Apply warm paste of crushed rhizome to joint pain or headaches twice daily
Add small piece of rhizome to curries/soups to support appetite and digestion
Use 500â€¯mg extract daily has shown improvement in SSRI-induced ED over 4 weeks
caution: May interact with sedatives and anticoagulantsâ€”avoid before surgery
Insufficient safety data for pregnancy, nursing, or children under 2
High doses may cause gastrointestinal upset or heartburn
1.foundIn: Native to Southeast Asia (Indonesia, Thailand); widely cultivated in India

2.name: Ariveâ€‘Dantu
uses: Antiâ€‘inflammatory and analgesic for wounds & swelling
Rich in iron, calcium, vitaminsâ€”tonic and nutritive
Helps soothe skin irritations and minor burns
Used traditionally to heal cuts and reduce bleeding
howToUse: Cook as a leafy green vegetable; consume daily for nutritional boost
Crush fresh leaves into a poultice and apply on wounds for 30â€¯min
Blend leaves into shawls/decoction, strain, and drink for antiâ€‘inflammatory effect
caution: Contains oxalatesâ€”excess may contribute to kidney stones
Not recommended for thyroid patients without medical advice
Wash thoroughly; wild-harvested amaranth can carry pesticides
2.foundIn: Common weed across tropical Asia and Africa

3.name: Palm Tree
uses: Date and coconut fruits for nutrition
Sap used to make jaggery, sugar, and drinking beverages
Leaves for shelter, weaving, roofing materials
Oil used in cooking, cosmetics, and for cosmic/ritual purposes
howToUse: Eat fresh or processed fruit (coconut flesh, water, dates) as daily food
Boil palm sap and reduce to make palm sugar or jaggery
Use young leaves to weave baskets, mats, roofing
